gestures.plaintext: “A moral govt not incompatible with general laws (no, nor with absolute decrees, per-haps, surely not, if many passages of scripture are true) for if we allow that those laws were origenally pasd by a moral Governor, they are from the beginning adapted to moral purposes, those parts therefor in the moral system w’h appear deviations from what we call general laws of nature & ways of Provi may be in fact only a part of them tho’ the sight is too dim to see their connection. These tho’ts readily reconcile the notion of prescience & an overruling Provi. for in fact the same thing.”

gestures.plaintext: “In viewing the operations of the Deity, we wer surrounded with infinity of forms, of combination—of magnitudes, of space, of time. The final object of knowlegde is to give us more perfect notions of the supreme Being, & to make us more reciprocally usefull. The degree in w’h we can be usefull, depends in a great measur on the degree according to w’h we can rightly estimate the powers of nature, and according to wh the degree in w’h we know how the Supreme Being adapts the train of causation to the end to be produced. The farther advances we make to the source of all intelligence, we more reason we have to admire his perfections & reverence his power. Admiration must generate the desire of imatation; & serious impressions of religious veneration must give life to a sentiment of universal love & charity.”

gestures.plaintext: The heathen had strange notions of fate they said it was uncontroulable by the gods—tho’ they never attributed to it any virtue. It seems they had some ideas w’h are interwoven with the mind of nessisity.

          <lb/>with a federal head—born innocent in the most <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><orig>po<seg read="- " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><lb break="no"/>fit</orig><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><reg><seg read="per-" type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><lb break="no"/><seg read="fect" type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></reg><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice> sense—free in the most perfect manner, the

          <lb/>every possible existence was always present—always
          <lb/>and nessecarily connected with His will and agency—who <del>from a</del>
                  <lb/>formed the whole <subst><seg read=" " type="subst" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><del read="of" type="subst" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="subst" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><add hand="#MME">plan</add><seg read=" " type="subst" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></subst> of the creation and redemption
          <lb/>from a perfect view of all it’s consequences; to such a
          <lb/>believer, whose views are thus extended—a final res<seg read="- " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><lb break="no"/>toration becomes a kind of intuition. In the native
          <lb/>depravity of human, fallen nature, in its connection
          <lb/>with a <hi rend="underline()">first reperesentative</hi>, and it’s misterious and

                  <itg type="reference" source="b:IT50001" xml:id="f04i001"> <hi rend="underline()">all are</hi>
                  <lb/>
                  <hi rend="underline()">made alive</hi></itg>—in the nessisity of a foreign and divine
          <lb/>agency to conversion, are found supports of the restora<seg read="- " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><lb break="no"/>tion from scripture of an unanswerable nature, with<seg read="- " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><lb break="no"/>out adverting to those numerous select passages which
          <lb/>support this belief— And in truth, I know not where
          <ab type="pbGroup" subtype="add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"><pb ed="HM" n="41"/>
                  <pb ed="GT" n="F13,SI" type="continued"/>
                  <pb ed="BP" n="2"/>
                  </ab><lb/>
                  <ab type="pbGroup" subtype="add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"><mw type="pageNum" rend="align(left) encircled" xml:id="tn.sec.427a" read="6" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/>
                  </ab><lb/>they are, nor what they are.</itg>
gestures.plaintext: degree of liberty and freedom of will (which does not appear philosophical or scriptural to the calvinistic Inquirier) that I should look for the belief, the sublime and godlike belief that human misery will find an universal remedy. To him, who views every man as unconnected with a federal head—born innocent in the most pofit sense—free in the most perfect manner, the scheme of eternal anguish may be more consistent with the manifest attributes of God and the nature of things. But to the consistent Calvinist, who believes in a God without succession of ideas—to whom the future of every possible existence was always present—always and nessecarily connected with His will and agency—who from a formed the whole plan of the creation and redemption from a perfect view of all it’s consequences; to such a believer, whose views are thus extended—a final restoration becomes a kind of intuition. In the native depravity of human, fallen nature, in its connection with a first reperesentative, and it’s misterious and aggrandising relation to a Second by whom came all are made alive—in the nessisity of a foreign and divine agency to conversion, are found supports of the restoration from scripture of an unanswerable nature, without adverting to those numerous select passages which support this belief— And in truth, I know not where they are, nor what they are.

gestures.excerpt:

        <lb/>ready to compare them to <hi rend="underline()">comets</hi>, whose light was splendid—
        <lb/>but terrific—whose <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><orig>excentrice</orig><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><reg read="eccentric" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice> revolutions while they

        <lb/>with new light the whole planetary world!</itg>

                     <lb/>immortal, but that <hi rend="underline()">it</hi> may refute the objections to its being
          <lb/>able to exist in a seperate state from body.”</itg> 
                  “our knowlegde 
          <lb/>of <hi rend="underline()">nature</hi> of mind too feeble to afford us <hi rend="underline()">positive</hi> 
                     <del>knowlegde</del> argument.
                  <lb/>One evidencee of a future state is <itg source="bibliography.xml#NA_Review_of_New_Publications" type="paraphrase">the <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><abbr>founda<hi rend="sup()">n</hi>
                        </abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><expan read="foundation" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice> 
                     <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><abbr>w’h</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><expan read="which" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice> 
                     <del>are</del> is laid
          <lb/>in the priciples of our constitution for a progressive &
          <lb/>& unlimited <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><abbr>improv<hi rend="sup()underline()">t</hi>
                        </abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><expan read="improvement" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice></itg>
                   
                   Another is <quote source="bibliography.xml#NA_Review_of_New_Publications" rend="pre(“)post()">“the natural apprehension
          <lb/>of the mind when under remorse.</quote> On the moral <supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">attri</supplied><seg read=" " type="explicit-whitespace" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><lb break="no"/>butes he calls them benevolence & justice—for the <gap desc="handwriting" reason="damaged"/>
                     <ab type="pbGroup" subtype="add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"><pb ed="HM" n="473"/>
                     <pb ed="GT" n="F41"/>
                     <pb ed="BP" n="2"/>
                     </ab><lb/>he thinks we have a stronge <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><abbr>argu.</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><expan read="argument" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice> 
                     <hi rend="underline()">
                        <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><orig>aprior</orig><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><reg read="apriori" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice>
                     </hi> from the ex<seg read=" " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><lb break="no"/>quisite pleasure our benivolent acts give us & the appro<seg read="- " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><lb break="no"/>bation we feel at others beneficence.
               </itg>
gestures.plaintext: D. Stewart says, in his outlines it is not the proper use of the doctrine of imme. of soul to show that it is phisically & nessesirly immortal, but that it may refute the objections to its being able to exist in a seperate state from body.” “our knowlegde of nature of mind too feeble to afford us positive knowlegde argument. One evidencee of a future state is the foundan w’h are is laid in the priciples of our constitution for a progressive & & unlimited improvt Another is “the natural apprehension of the mind when under remorse. On the moral attributes he calls them benevolence & justice—for the he thinks we have a stronge argu. aprior from the exquisite pleasure our benivolent acts give us & the approbation we feel at others beneficence.

gestures.plaintext: I have been weake for many moments. God most holy I plead thy promises— I bring the arguments of my misery—do more for me—crushed by exteriors—appear for my spirit—if I cannot serve thee—love thee and fear thee I do not wish for any mode of existence. If I cannot glorify thee in life let me die to honor thee die and perceive thee—know order & forever & unceasingly obey it. Perhaps my pride suffers—perhaps were I larger these failures would not pain me so— While mortal I shall sin— I do not wish to be other than human—for then I sd be without out of the pale of xianity —blessed province w’h binds the redeemed nearer the throne of the Creator! Perhaps, here Paul gloried in infirmity.

gestures.plaintext: This 7th lect abounds with illustrations & lights on the econymy of Provedence of lasting value adorned by an eloquence w’h must rivet attention. If the conservitive disputes the value of machinery and the moral power of the best Artist, his acrimony will be softened. If he still recurs to the sad facts of true and ever honored genius like Dante Columbus and numbers of suffering talents (even the xian Young who meanly wished the notice of a Queen), the favor of pub-lick & its oracles were nessceary to aid his their powers & brighten their declening life. How many amiable Keates have actually died? And it will always be a doubt, with the obscure & ignorant, whether the arts & science itself have aided made the most stronge & martyr spirits to the cross & to the publick welfare? There are problemns of an exclusive religious nature w’h lie at the basis of human existence w’h even this pow-erfull writer as yet has not solved & probably never can be in this life by the profoundest & widest phi-losophy, but w’h xianity alone remidies by a faith w’h is supernatural. More than faith—the certainty of its truths coeval with & developing the intuiteons of the heart. Here is the “certitude,” w’h even Morell cannot improve. It is content with what is nessecarily mysterious as it is an inevitable condition of a being like man, and often adds to the charms of his future prospects in the worlds of knowledge and indescrible joy of studying the Infinite! Here lies the glorious effect of this lecture, when by a few facts of the wonders of that God gift by w’h the idea of the powers of the Creator were bro’t to veiw in His works! Then the most imprisoned & limited soul finds an ark of safty in this incompre-hensible and boundless Being thro the medium of His Son! And mysteries & a world of complicated ills all vanish and the restoration of the time worn race gives a consolation w’h no delighfell prospects of its “progress” here can equal. More more lectures!

More than faith—the certainty of <lb/>its truths coeval
              with & developing the <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><orig>intuiteons</orig><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><reg read="intuitions" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice> of the <lb/>heart. Here is the <quote source="bibliography.xml#Schlegel_Philosophy bibliography.xml#Morell_Tendencies">“<hi rend="underline()">certitude</hi>,”</quote> <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><abbr>w’h</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><expan read="which" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice> even <persName key="JM4">Morell</persName> cannot <lb/>improve.</itg>
gestures.plaintext: There are problemns of an exclusive religious nature w’h lie at the basis of human existence w’h even this pow-erfull writer as yet has not solved & probably never can be in this life by the profoundest & widest phi-losophy, but w’h xianity alone remidies by a faith w’h is supernatural. More than faith—the certainty of its truths coeval with & developing the intuiteons of the heart. Here is the “certitude,” w’h even Morell cannot improve.

gestures.plaintext: “certitude,”

gestures.plaintext: It is content with what is nessecarily mysterious as it is an inevitable condition of a being like man, and often adds to the charms of his future prospects in the worlds of knowledge and indescrible joy of studying the Infinite! Here lies the glorious effect of this lecture, when by a few facts of the wonders of that God gift by w’h the idea of the powers of the Creator were bro’t to veiw in His works! Then the most imprisoned & limited soul finds an ark of safty in this incompre-hensible and boundless Being thro the medium of His Son! And mysteries & a world of complicated ills all vanish and the restoration of the time worn race gives a consolation w’h no delighfell prospects of its “progress” here can equal

<quote xmlns="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase" xml:id="ANN002" source="bibliography.xml#Morell_Philosophy">“The great spheres to <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><abbr>w’h</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><expan read="which" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice> our intu-<lb break="no"/>itions are <add xml:id="TN006">directed</add> are
            those of the <hi rend="underline()">beautifull</hi> the <hi rend="underline()">good</hi>
            <lb/>and <hi rend="underline()">true</hi>, & corresponding to these are three
            classes <lb/>of emotion aesthetical, the moral and those hitherto un-<lb break="no"/>named heavings of the spirit, when it contemplates the <lb/>awfull majesty and
            immensity of <hi rend="underline()">Being</hi>—pure eternal <lb/>Being”!</quote>
gestures.plaintext: “The great spheres to w’h our intu-itions are directed are those of the beautifull the good and true, & corresponding to these are three classes of emotion aesthetical, the moral and those hitherto un-named heavings of the spirit, when it contemplates the awfull majesty and immensity of Being—pure eternal Being”!

Well there

gestures.plaintext: But this hour I pass them, & all his cool calatons to the Absolute the nessecary glorious first Cause. There lives the eternal and I in Him by nessesity of creation. Halleluia. A moment & comes the sins weakneses & disgraces w’h have kept me penitent these tedious times of ill health. Well there comes the Cross, who tho possibly the agent & priest of worlds before ours, yet died after sufferings, from w’h he shrunk, to fill the awfull chasm w’h sin had made between God & man, and to individual misery a safty & assurance.

            <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">m</supplied>atters? Were there none of this
            connection <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">a</supplied>nd no cause existing
            but the Absolute then <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">we</supplied>re we
              <hi rend="underline()">perhaps</hi> more sure of the infinite <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">w</supplied>orth of this capasity—gift or inspiration!
              <lb/><seg xml:id="TN005"><supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">If</supplied></seg>
            so & how antagonist to my very existince is <lb/><supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">th</supplied>e lament of <persName key="JGF1">Fitche</persName> about his

gestures.plaintext: Is it in the nature of things that an external rev. should thus induce faith (more requisite for the absolute invalid than for the stake) without it’s internal adaptation to soul—it’s natural, like the connection betwen cause & effect in phisial matters? Were there none of this connection and no cause existing but the Absolute then were we perhaps more sure of the infinite worth of this capasity—gift or inspiration! If so & how antagonist to my very existince is the lament of Fitche about his being a mere recipient—a spectator—an unwilling agent.

gestures.plaintext: Plotinus says truly “no one will behold this light speaking of the vision of God the supreme, who is drawn downwards by things w’h are an impediment to this vision” “This One is not absent from any thing and yet is seperated from all things; so that it is present & not present with them. But it is present with those things that are able & prepared to recive it so that they be-come congruous & as it were pass into contact with it thro’ similitude & a certain inherent power allied to that w’h is imparted by the one.” Here is genuine truth of reason & coeval with the latest rev.! Dear sainted Plotinus! “God is not in a certain place so as to desert other things; but wherever any thing is able to come in contact with Him there not He is present.”. “Cause howevr is not the same with the thing caused.” Hence must it not be denominated that good w’h it imparts to others; but it is another manner the good, in a way transcending other goods.”— I” — — If the soul wishes to abide on high she will consider potitical concerns unwothy to be the subjects of conference with the Deity. For this will be his language who has seen much of divinity. For as it is said, God is not external to any one but is present with all things, tho’ they are ignorant that he is so for they fly from Him, rather from themselves.”

gestures.plaintext: Chap. on the One. Plotinus reminds of w’h the artist says are in the quarry. Revelation have discovered a nobler decided faith & appre-hensions) of the Divinity than the highest tho’t of artist ever gave to the Statue w’h had been laboured into form of more than mortal beauty. What clouds & shawdows bedim that bright Spirit when labouring to produce into form the simpleist & grandest ideas of God—ideas & elements w’h constitute a soul! And w’h when developed by foreign aid become so united to prac-tical and intuitive reason.

gestures.plaintext: 14 sab Eve And yet when he de-scribes the nature & affinities of soul how may the xian be put a back who hesitates whether it is immediately consious after death. One would almost wish they had nver heard of the resurrec-tion of body, & tho wholly indifferent to its rising yet so mingled are the duties—so wholly the xian dis-cipline seems to depend on it with the obscure truth we can’t separate it easily.

gestures.plaintext: “Hence it is nessecay to hastend our departure from hence to be indignant that we are bound to one part of our nature, in order that with the whole of our true selves may we may fold oursleves about divinity & have no part void of contact with him! When this takes place therefore, the soul will both see divinity and herself, as far as it is lawful for her to see him.

gestures.plaintext: And how clearly does Plotinus reprsent the state (w’h cannot be explained,) of the vision—or extacy expansion & accession or going out of one’s self” the prohets!! even the princly Isaiah or herd of xians! “If howver he has entered the Adytum he obtains a true vision—if not entered, he will conceiv this Adytum to be a certain invisible thing, & will have a knowledge of the fountain & priciple of things. But when situated there, he will see the principle, & be conjoined with it, by a union of like with like, neglecting nothing divine w’h the soul is able to possess.” “Prior to the vision also it requirs that w’h remains from the vision. But that w’h remains to him who passes beyond all things is that w’h is prior to all things. For the nature of the soul will never accede to that w’h is intirely non being. But proceeding indeed downwards it falls into evil & thus into non being, yet not that w’h is perfect non entity. Running, howevr, in a contrary deriction it arises not at another thing, but at itself. To be in itself alone, and not in being, is to be in God. For God is somthing w’h is not essence but beyond essence. Hence the soul when in this condition associa-tes with Him. — — — — And if he passes from himself as an image to the Archetype, he will then have the end of his progression. But when he falls from the vision of God, if he from the vision, if he again excites the vir-tue w’h is in himself, & percies himself to be perfectly adorned; he will again be ele-vated thro’ vitue, proceeding to intellet & wis-dom, & afterwards to the priciple of all things.” Alas, had the soul not arived to this Priciple

gestures.plaintext: “If howver he has entered the Adytum he obtains a true vision—if not entered, he will conceiv this Adytum to be a certain invisible thing, & will have a knowledge of the fountain & priciple of things. But when situated there, he will see the principle, & be conjoined with it, by a union of like with like, neglecting nothing divine w’h the soul is able to possess.” “Prior to the vision also it requirs that w’h remains from the vision. But that w’h remains to him who passes beyond all things is that w’h is prior to all things. For the nature of the soul will never accede to that w’h is intirely non being. But proceeding indeed downwards it falls into evil & thus into non being, yet not that w’h is perfect non entity. Running, howevr, in a contrary deriction it arises not at another thing, but at itself. To be in itself alone, and not in being, is to be in God. For God is somthing w’h is not essence but beyond essence. Hence the soul when in this condition associa-tes with Him. — — — — And if he passes from himself as an image to the Archetype, he will then have the end of his progression. But when he falls from the vision of God, if he from the vision, if he again excites the vir-tue w’h is in himself, & percies himself to be perfectly adorned; he will again be ele-vated thro’ vitue, proceeding to intellet & wis-dom, & afterwards to the priciple of all things.”

            <lb/><choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><abbr>w’h</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><expan read="which" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice> is posterior.”</itg></itg>
gestures.plaintext: And what cognisences of God dwelt in these men, their life partakes of Deiety how below the xian trintity— yet respected. And how destinct their intuition of the One till they smothered it by theories. I the chap. on “immotality of Soul” would shame the best of the materialists by the strenght of its arguments on its indivisible real nature? Alas! it seemed that mine was divisible much of the time to all skey & earthly influences. And when the moments of concentration is given it seems to idealise the eternal “nows” of time of my noble author. If a cloud or tree seemd a part of me this morning—’twas but as a lar On time—they are confused when calling it the same with eternity—why not rest there—for it is only named & parceled out by planets and the sad history of man, who has made of it a god—& sacrifices body & soul to its molock claims. Time as an abstract idea was always—oh tre-mendous time what hast thou numbered since the fleeting race have given thee But hear the Sage “It is requisite that we should betake ourselves to that condition of being w’h we say is in eternity; a condition w’h is im-mutable, & at once total, a life now infinite and perfectly flexible and abiding in one, and directed to the One”. He gose on to speake of time “generated by the reason & nature of that w’h is posterior.”

gestures.plaintext: “Time an image of eternity” in the stillness of the “wilderness where God hath built,” at mid-night it thus becomes, undefiled—unstunned and we cannot say with the philosopher “that the Demiurgus made day & night to apprehend two things— — —from w’h Plato said they arived at the conception of number” They might—but night & day too was made for nobler—infinite pur-poses! But hear him on clearer ground. “Who-ever fancies that beings governed by chance or fortune & are held togather by corporeal causes is very remote from God & conception of the One

gestures.plaintext: Thou art more—as one of my antients say—“a proceeding intellect, established indeed in eternity but proceeding & abundantly flowing int the things w’h are gaurded by it” But more grand grand & clear is time streching his immeasurble tremendous wings thro’ the fathomless past & future by being “the mode of Gods existence the existence of duration.” Rather may we pass to the venerable Clarke & say it is the very life of God that constitues time & splace!

gestures.plaintext: Glorious—tell us not dear & venerable Clark that virtue (in nature & origin) does not originate crated in creatures in His will —it is the eternal fittness—to w’h it is our eter optimism to conform—utility for immutable perfection—“sympathy” with the origian of morals—not debased forms of it in man. If Waldo had given? his spiritual wrld this will I should better have understood the inlargment of ours to it as the source of the moral.

gestures.plaintext: Why was thy veneable head so misled by the natural conclusions of Spinozaism—puts all of poor imprisoned cratures in a govt free & material. But were there but “one Substance relative & extensive infinitly.” & every thing modifications of it”—the old forgery, of the bible God, would still hope to be a modification of joy & hope—he would at the sight of sin & misery say this modification is a nessecay evil?— —but does not impeach the infinite bene-volence of the Being who is united by nesesity to the destiny of univesal society. True, there is neither reason nor sense here but feeling. Ah how impossible to demonstrate by reasonings what “pretumuous reason” feels. But against nesseity in bad senses of Spinozaism, the indilible characters on the soul are the sure demonstrations—these triumph over all the plausibilietites of heretics in nat. or rev. theology—philosophy & science. Oppose it with themselves they become mere phenomena

<itg xmlns="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase" xmlns:wms="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase/manuscript" type="distillation" xml:id="an001" source="bibliography.xml#Grove_System bibliography.xml#Stewart_Philosophical_Essays" cert="medium">This morning I read a
             <lb/>“few sentences of the <hi rend="underline()">certainty of</hi> morality!

             <lb/>
             <hi rend="underline()">I love</hi>) should be the fountain & origin of
             <lb/>all morality— But my ideas have alwys
             <lb/>been confused—as led to faith & piety before
             <lb/>the theory of morals. But could it not exist
             <lb/>in the eternal and have no relation or obli<seg read="- " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><lb break="no"/>gation to man were man only a <hi rend="underline()">body</hi> with<seg read="- " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><lb break="no"/>out any attributes of spirit. Where would be
             <lb/>
             <del>the</del> what is falsly called the <quote source="bibliography.xml#Grove_System" xml:id="f36i001">moral <hi rend="underline()">sense</hi></quote>
             <ab type="pbGroup" subtype="add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"><pb ed="HM" n="451b"/>
             <pb ed="GT" n="F32"/>
             <pb ed="BP" n="3"/>
             </ab><lb/>—where any congruity between the eternal
             <lb/>obligations of right conduct and <subst><seg read=" " type="subst" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><del read="the" type="subst" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="subst" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><add>a</add><seg read=" " type="subst" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></subst> creature
             <lb/>without any <hi rend="underline()">principles inherent</hi>, <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><abbr>w’h</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><expan read="which" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice> are
             <lb/>adopted to morality? All application of
             <lb/>religion must thus be <hi rend="underline()">miraculous</hi>.</itg>
gestures.plaintext: This morning I read a “few sentences of the certainty of morality! I used to choose that the will of God (whom I love) should be the fountain & origin of all morality— But my ideas have alwys been confused—as led to faith & piety before the theory of morals. But could it not exist in the eternal and have no relation or obligation to man were man only a body without any attributes of spirit. Where would be the what is falsly called the moral sense —where any congruity between the eternal obligations of right conduct and a creature without any principles inherent, w’h are adopted to morality? All application of religion must thus be miraculous.

gestures.excerpt:
<quote xmlns="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase" xmlns:wms="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase/manuscript" source="bibliography.xml#Rollin_Ancient_History" rend="post()" xml:id="f02i002">“Whilst all things
<lb/>are in motion & fluctuate on the earth; whilst states & empires
<lb/>pass away with incredible swiftness, & the human race
<lb/>vainly employed in the external view of these things, are
<lb/>also drawn in by the same torrent, almost without <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><abbr>percvng</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><expan read="perceiving" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice>
                     <lb/>it, there passes in secret an order & disposition of things un<seg read=" " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><lb break="no"/>known & invisible, <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><abbr>w’h</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><expan read="which" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice>, however, determine our fate to
<lb/>all eternity. The duration of ages has no other end than
<lb/>the formation of the bodies of the elect <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><abbr>w’h</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><expan read="which" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice> augments, &
<lb/>
                     <supplied reason="damaged" source="#RollinAncientHistory">ten</supplied>ds daily to perfection. When it shall receive its
  <lb/>
                     <supplied reason="damaged" source="#RollinAncientHistory">final</supplied> <supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">accom</supplied>plishment by the death of the last elect</quote>
gestures.plaintext: “Whilst all things are in motion & fluctuate on the earth; whilst states & empires pass away with incredible swiftness, & the human race vainly employed in the external view of these things, are also drawn in by the same torrent, almost without percvng it, there passes in secret an order & disposition of things unknown & invisible, w’h, however, determine our fate to all eternity. The duration of ages has no other end than the formation of the bodies of the elect w’h augments, & tends daily to perfection. When it shall receive its final accomplishment by the death of the last elect

                     </abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><expan read="softened" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice> tints of past misfortune and the
<lb/>liveliness of future hopes—in fine it is the
<lb/>medium of every joy and harmonises all the
<lb/>soul. As long as idenity exists so long the perog<seg read="- " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><lb break="no"/>ative of a happy <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><abbr>imaja<hi rend="sup() underline()">n</hi>
                     </abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><expan read="imagination" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice> will remain: the pecu<seg read=" " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><lb break="no"/>liar gifts, the indefinable combinations of genius
<lb/>will never be the portion of vulgar souls (it
<lb/>seems) even in ages of blessedness! They may grow
<lb/>expatiate and triumph in the devolving wonders
<lb/>of a God, but by analogy of all human education
<lb/>they will not acquire gifts different from the
<lb/>stamina—the constituent principles <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><abbr>w’h</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><expan read="which" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice> compose
<lb/>the soul.— <hi rend="underline()">the Soul</hi> what is it? whatever it
<lb/>be, it’s stamp is given—it’s features are indelibly
<lb/>stamped for eternity at it’s formation—education
<lb/>forms—marrs—or perfects them—and supernal
<lb/>influence directs & sanctifys them. We antiscipate
<lb/>new powers in eternity—true, but they will
<lb/>be in unison perhaps to those we exercise now—nay<supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">,</supplied>
                  <lb/>
                  <supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">th</supplied>e germ—the embreyo of every principle mu<supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">st</supplied>
                  <lb/>
                  <supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">lie wi</supplied>thin us</itg>
gestures.plaintext: It is to imajanation that faculty of the mind w’h seems to unite the feelings of the heart to the exertions of intellect that are ver the softd tints of past misfortune and the liveliness of future hopes—in fine it is the medium of every joy and harmonises all the soul. As long as idenity exists so long the perogative of a happy imajan will remain: the peculiar gifts, the indefinable combinations of genius will never be the portion of vulgar souls (it seems) even in ages of blessedness! They may grow expatiate and triumph in the devolving wonders of a God, but by analogy of all human education they will not acquire gifts different from the stamina—the constituent principles w’h compose the soul.— the Soul what is it? whatever it be, it’s stamp is given—it’s features are indelibly stamped for eternity at it’s formation—education forms—marrs—or perfects them—and supernal influence directs & sanctifys them. We antiscipate new powers in eternity—true, but they will be in unison perhaps to those we exercise now—nay, the germ—the embreyo of every principle must lie within us

<lb/>it were humanised the idea of the Divinity, &
<lb/>
                     <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><abbr>bro’t</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><expan read="brought" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice> it as it were somewhat nearer to us, there
<lb/>
                     <supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">w</supplied>as little said about the love of God. The followers
<lb/>
                     <supplied reason="damaged" source="#Burke_Enquiry">of Plato</supplied> had somthing of it, & only somthing, the othe<supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">r</supplied>
                     <lb/>
                     <supplied reason="damaged" source="#Burke_Enquiry">writers of</supplied> pagan <supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">an</supplied>tiquity, whether Poets or philosophers,
<lb/>
                     <supplied reason="damaged" source="#Burke_Enquiry">nothing at all. And they who</supplied> <supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">consider</supplied> with <supplied reason="damaged" source="#Burke_Enquiry">what</supplied>
                     <ab type="pbGroup" subtype="add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"><pb ed="HM" n="18"/>
                     <pb ed="GT" n="F2,S8" type="continued"/>
                     <pb ed="BP" n="18"/></ab>
infinite attention, by what a disregard of i<supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">m</supplied><seg read=" " type="explicit-whitespace" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><lb break="no"/>perishable object, <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><abbr>thro’</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><expan read="through" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice> what long habits of <supplied reason="damaged" source="#Burke_Enquiry">piety</supplied>
                     <lb/>& contemplation it is, any man is able to attain <supplied reason="damaged" source="#Burke_Enquiry">an</supplied>
                     <lb/>intire love & devotion to the Deity, will easily
<lb/>perceive that it is not the first, the most
<lb/>
                     <del>striking</del> natural, and the most striking effect
<lb/>which proceeds from that idea.”</quote>
gestures.plaintext: “Before the xian religion had as it were humanised the idea of the Divinity, & bro’t it as it were somewhat nearer to us, there was little said about the love of God. The followers of Plato had somthing of it, & only somthing, the other writers of pagan antiquity, whether Poets or philosophers, nothing at all. And they who consider with what infinite attention, by what a disregard of imperishable object, thro’ what long habits of piety & contemplation it is, any man is able to attain an intire love & devotion to the Deity, will easily perceive that it is not the first, the most striking natural, and the most striking effect which proceeds from that idea.”

gestures.plaintext: It is said by the invidi-ous Gibbon that while the Vatican has been so disfigured that were the Apostles to revisit it they would not know it, the lofty dome of St Sophia retains the representation of the humble tabernacle of Medina. And that while chistian commentaries have so disfigured the text as wd oblige their original authors to study thier own writings, the koran remains the infallible code of religious & civil legislation. In this blending of sacred & civvil interests it is true Gibbon finds the cause of the permancy of mohammedan ism.

gestures.plaintext: If there is any possible or established connction between means & ends—asking & finding, I’ll seek that the dark cloud of ignorance be removed in a measure consistent with my condition & my hopes as a believr in a divine relation & agency. Edwards speaking of these connections says. “The supposed connetion betwen antecedents & consequ ents let it be ever so sure & nessecay does not does not prove that it is in vain for a man to attempt to open, his eyes—his aiming—& the use of means being the effect of his will does not breake the connection nor hinder the success.” May not the free will of a moral Agent be a link in the chain of events each of which is ordered by God—and yet the free-dom not the less than if any temporey motive—or accident had induced the will to act. In short, it seems that the will of a being with a moral capasity is nothing more than an instru-ment of the divine govt of the most misterious kind in living to issue the most stupendous schemes according to the Edwards’ system.

gestures.excerpt:
<itg xmlns="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase" xmlns:wms="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase/manuscript" type="reference" guessture="dialogic-reference" xml:id="ANN015" source="bibliography.xml#Butler_Analogy">It is well to be ware of the delu<seg read="- " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><lb break="no"/>sion of <hi rend="underline()">feelings</hi>—what are called <hi rend="underline()">frames</hi>— And in every
          <lb/>ssubject there <hi rend="underline()">may</hi> be delusion. In the speculations of the most
          <lb/>prolific brain on the deepest, are often errors of immense
          <lb/>size, obvious to the <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><orig>plainst</orig><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><reg read="plainest" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice> sense— In every science, in every
          <lb/>department of philosophy, save experimental (poor sensible
          <lb/>manual experiment) there has been found deceptions
          <lb/>& errors from the wildest to the most <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><orig>desipacable</orig><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><reg read="despicable" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice> kind.
          <lb/>Then where is certainty and what are its surest li<seg read="- " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><lb break="no"/>mits? Why not <hi rend="underline()">in feeling</hi>? We all know <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><orig>whither</orig><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><reg read="whether" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice> we
          <lb/>are at ease, whether suffering the nameless pangs of
          <lb/>restlessness, ill humour and dreaded apathy, or <subst><seg read=" " type="subst" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><del read="these" type="subst" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="subst" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><add>tasting</add><seg read=" " type="subst" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></subst>
                  <lb/>the indiscrible joys of sympathy, benvolence & activity.
          <lb/>Here is <hi rend="underline()">experiment</hi> in the very essence of the soul &
          <lb/>surerr than those of matter—for some say, there is
          <lb/>
                  <hi rend="underline()">no body</hi>. In <hi rend="underline()">consciousness there can be no delusion</hi>, even
                <lb/>where <hi rend="underline()">no body nor <del rend="struck(single)">&</del>
                  </hi>
                  <hi rend="underline()">spiri</hi>t in the world. And when concsious
          <lb/>of <subst><seg read=" " type="subst" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><del read="motions" type="subst" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="subst" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><add>the</add><seg read=" " type="subst" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></subst> perfections of God, without
          <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><orig>raticiconation</orig><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><reg read="ratiocination" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice>, the joy
          <lb/>is certain & <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><orig>infablible</orig><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><reg read="infallible" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice>—so of every other sentiment which
          <lb/>inraptures & ennobles. If <persName key="JB1">Butler</persName> meant these <hi rend="underline()">feelings</hi>,
          <lb/>when he said somthing (I almost forget) about weaken<seg read="- " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><lb break="no"/>ing the priciples of action, then I wont believe him,
          <lb/>
                  <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><abbr>tho’</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><expan read="though" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice> I seldom pass a week without trembling at his
          <lb/>verdict—without desiring <hi rend="underline()">to do</hi>, to act, without the aid of
          <lb/>feeling. And mayhap the purest virtue is independent. But of
           <ab type="pbGroup" subtype="add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"><pb ed="HM" n="463b"/>
                  <pb ed="GT" n="F33"/>
                  <pb ed="BP" n="13"/>
                  </ab><lb/>what nature is vertue without <hi rend="underline()">consciousness</hi> of it? Does the
          <lb/>Martyr, the Reformer the Missionary act without feeling
          <lb/>a stronge <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><orig>persusion</orig><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><reg read="persuasion" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice> of the truth for <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><abbr>w’h</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><expan read="which" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice> he suffers. Does
          <lb/>he go <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><abbr>thro’</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><expan read="through" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice> incalculable sufferings guided only the cool dedu<seg read=" " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><lb break="no"/>tions of reason & the connection of truth? Probably <persName key="JB1">But<seg read="- " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><lb break="no"/>ler</persName> meant the proscription of feelings <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><abbr>w’h</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><expan read="which" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice> only swims in the
          <lb/>fancy—never warm the affections nor subdue the passions</itg>
gestures.plaintext: It is well to be ware of the delusion of feelings—what are called frames— And in every ssubject there may be delusion. In the speculations of the most prolific brain on the deepest, are often errors of immense size, obvious to the plainst sense— In every science, in every department of philosophy, save experimental (poor sensible manual experiment) there has been found deceptions & errors from the wildest to the most desipacable kind. Then where is certainty and what are its surest limits? Why not in feeling? We all know whither we are at ease, whether suffering the nameless pangs of restlessness, ill humour and dreaded apathy, or tasting the indiscrible joys of sympathy, benvolence & activity. Here is experiment in the very essence of the soul & surerr than those of matter—for some say, there is no body. In consciousness there can be no delusion, even where no body nor & spirit in the world. And when concsious of the perfections of God, without raticiconation, the joy is certain & infablible—so of every other sentiment which inraptures & ennobles. If Butler meant these feelings, when he said somthing (I almost forget) about weakening the priciples of action, then I wont believe him, tho’ I seldom pass a week without trembling at his verdict—without desiring to do, to act, without the aid of feeling. And mayhap the purest virtue is independent. But of what nature is vertue without consciousness of it? Does the Martyr, the Reformer the Missionary act without feeling a stronge persusion of the truth for w’h he suffers. Does he go thro’ incalculable sufferings guided only the cool dedutions of reason & the connection of truth? Probably Butler meant the proscription of feelings w’h only swims in the fancy—never warm the affections nor subdue the passions

gestures.excerpt: <quote xmlns="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase" xmlns:wms="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase/manuscript" rend="pre()post()underline()" xml:id="ANN016" cert="medium" ana="a:reference" source="b:IT50046">let me dispise my life</quote>

gestures.excerpt:
<itg xmlns="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase" xmlns:wms="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase/manuscript" type="reference" xml:id="ANN020" cert="low" source="bibliography.xml#CampbellandHume_Lectures bibliography.xml#NA_Augsburg_Confession bibliography.xml#Hazelius_Luther">I have been reading or rather poring over
            <lb/>
                  <persName key="ML1">Luther’s</persName> life. What an eternal wittness of the agency of God
            <lb/>with that of man! His sorrows misgivings & concessions
            <lb/>to Rome discover the natural workings of man. His
            <lb/>daring courage, his miraculous faith (without the <hi rend="underline()">show</hi>
                  <lb/>of miricle) bespeake the agency of God without a doubt.
            <lb/>How much richer a gift, how much more adapted to the
            <lb/>condition of man was the reformation by apparent (and in
            <lb/>some reality) by human methods than by miricle! The for<seg read="- " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><lb break="no"/>mation of <persName key="ML1">Luther’s</persName> mind was ordained by God as a means of
            <lb/>it, yet how many causes natural & coporeal were in the
            <lb/>chain!</itg>
gestures.plaintext: I have been reading or rather poring over Luther’s life. What an eternal wittness of the agency of God with that of man! His sorrows misgivings & concessions to Rome discover the natural workings of man. His daring courage, his miraculous faith (without the show of miricle) bespeake the agency of God without a doubt. How much richer a gift, how much more adapted to the condition of man was the reformation by apparent (and in some reality) by human methods than by miricle! The formation of Luther’s mind was ordained by God as a means of it, yet how many causes natural & coporeal were in the chain!

<quote xmlns="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase" xmlns:wms="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase/manuscript" source="bibliography.xml#Doddridge_Works" rend="pre() post()" xml:id="f40i001">The obligation
          <lb/>of the precepts con<seg read="- " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><lb break="no"/>taind in new <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><abbr>tes</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><expan read="testament" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice>
                  <lb/>continus so long as the
        <lb/>reasons on <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><abbr>w’h</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><expan read="which" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice> they were
        <lb/>founded continue, & ceases when
        <lb/>the observation of any particular precept
        <lb/>is inconsistent with another of a more
        <lb/>general nature, or of greater importance for
          <lb/>for promoting the essential branches of virtue.</quote>
gestures.plaintext: The obligation of the precepts containd in new tes continus so long as the reasons on w’h they were founded continue, & ceases when the observation of any particular precept is inconsistent with another of a more general nature, or of greater importance for for promoting the essential branches of virtue.

gestures.excerpt:
<quote xmlns="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase" xmlns:wms="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase/manuscript" source="bibliography.xml#Doddridge_Works" xml:id="f40i002">“1. Many precepts are delivered in
          <lb/>such manner, as that they must nessecerily admit of some exception, in
          <lb/>order to reconcile them with each other, & with the natural law of God, founded
          <lb/>on the mutual & immutable relation of things. 2. The <name>law of <persName>Moses</persName>
                     </name> which is deliverd
          <lb/>in as general & universal a stile as the precepts of Christ was in some instances
          viola<supplied reason="damaged" source="#gt">ted</supplied>
          without any crime by those who were still in
          general under the oblgations of that law”</quote>
gestures.plaintext: “1. Many precepts are delivered in such manner, as that they must nessecerily admit of some exception, in order to reconcile them with each other, & with the natural law of God, founded on the mutual & immutable relation of things. 2. The law of Moses which is deliverd in as general & universal a stile as the precepts of Christ was in some instances violated without any crime by those who were still in general under the oblgations of that law”

gestures.excerpt:
<quote xmlns="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase" xmlns:wms="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase/manuscript" type="misquotation" source="bibliography.xml#Bacon_Advancement" xml:id="f40i005">the only
          <lb/>
                  <q>“forms”</q> worthy of <persName key="P1">Plato</persName>
                  <lb/>were those abstracted from
          <lb/>matter. <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><abbr>Tho’</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><expan read="Though" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice>
                  <persName key="FB1">Bacon</persName> says
        <lb/>
                  <q>“he lost the advantage
        <lb/>of his opinion <hi rend="underline()">that
        <lb/>forms</hi> were the true
        <lb/>object of knowledge, by
        <lb/>grasping at those
        <lb/>which were <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><abbr>abstrcd</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><expan read="abstracted" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice>
                     <lb/>from matter & not
        <lb/>as determined in it.”</q>
                  <lb/>whence he turned
        <lb/>to theological <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><abbr>opinn</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><expan read="opinion" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice>
                  <lb/>& thence infected all
      <lb/>his <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><abbr>nat.</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><expan read="natural" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice>
                  <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><abbr>phi.</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><expan read="philosophy" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice>
                  <lb/>Did he ex<seg read="- " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><lb break="no"/>pect to
    <lb/>find forms
          <lb/>in theology</quote>
gestures.plaintext: the only “forms” worthy of Plato were those abstracted from matter. Tho’ Bacon says “he lost the advantage of his opinion that forms were the true object of knowledge, by grasping at those which were abstrcd from matter & not as determined in it.” whence he turned to theological opinn & thence infected all his nat. phi. Did he expect to find forms in theology

<quote xmlns="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase" xmlns:wms="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase/manuscript" xml:id="an45.0" source="bibliography.xml#Gillies_Aristotles_Ethics">Time an affection of motion

          <lb/>unobstructed exercise of their powers

          <lb/>exceeds comprehension.</quote>
gestures.plaintext: Time an affection of motion of w’h God is Author That kind of life which the best & happiest men lead occasionly, in the unobstructed exercise of their powers belongs eternally to God in a degree that should excite admiration in proportion as it exceeds comprehension.

                  <lb/>
                  <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><abbr>w’h</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><expan read="which" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice>, being linked indissolubly together unite the most distant & aparent extremes.</quote>

gestures.excerpt:
<itg xmlns="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase" xmlns:wms="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase/manuscript" type="paraphrase" source="bibliography.xml#Reid_Inquiry" xml:id="f40i013">“The dissimilitude of our sensations
                  <lb/>& feelings to external things is the innocent Mother of
                  <lb/>those frightfull progeny—that terminates in saying
                  <lb/>that there exists nothing but ideas & impressions—
                  <lb/>that there are no causes nor effects; no substances ma<seg read=" " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><lb break="no"/>terial or spiritual; no evidencee even in mathematical demon<seg read=" " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><lb break="no"/>stration; no liberty nor active power; nothing existing in na<seg read=" " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><lb break="no"/>ture but impressions & ideas following each other with<seg read=" " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><lb break="no"/>out time or place or subject.” He says too that the ex<seg read=" " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><lb break="no"/>pectation of the connection of two events is not an <term key="association">associa<seg read=" " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><lb break="no"/>tion of ideas</term> but a precsience of mind”</itg>
gestures.plaintext: “The dissimilitude of our sensations & feelings to external things is the innocent Mother of those frightfull progeny—that terminates in saying that there exists nothing but ideas & impressions— that there are no causes nor effects; no substances material or spiritual; no evidencee even in mathematical demonstration; no liberty nor active power; nothing existing in nature but impressions & ideas following each other without time or place or subject.” He says too that the expectation of the connection of two events is not an association of ideas but a precsience of mind”

gestures.excerpt:
<itg xmlns="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase" xmlns:wms="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase/manuscript" type="paraphrase" source="bibliography.xml#Reid_Inquiry" xml:id="f40i014">And he calls
            <lb/>this <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><abbr>prn.</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><expan read="principle" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice> not the effect of reasoning but an original priciple
            <lb/>of <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><abbr>hu.</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><expan read="human" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice>
                     <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><abbr>na.</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><expan read="nature" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice>
                     <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><abbr>w’h</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><expan read="which" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice> he calls the <hi rend="underline()">inductive <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><abbr>prin.</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><expan read="principle" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice>
                     </hi> The best models of
          <lb/>inductive reasoning those of <persName key="SIN1">Newtons</persName>
                     <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><sic>prinipia</sic><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><corr read="principia" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice> & opticks drawn from
            <lb/>
                     <persName key="FB1">Bacon</persName>. The purpose to show us
            <hi rend="underline()">real</hi> & <hi rend="underline()">apparent</hi> connections of
            <lb/>things in Nature.”</itg>
gestures.plaintext: And he calls this prn. not the effect of reasoning but an original priciple of hu. na. w’h he calls the inductive prin. The best models of inductive reasoning those of Newtons prinipia & opticks drawn from Bacon. The purpose to show us real & apparent connections of things in Nature.”

gestures.excerpt: <itg xmlns="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase" xmlns:wms="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase/manuscript" type="intertextual_echo" source="bibliography.xml#Reid_Inquiry" cert="low" xml:id="f40i015">enthu<seg read=" " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><lb break="no"/>siasm as a disease—</itg>

gestures.excerpt:
<itg xmlns="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase" xmlns:wms="http://www.wwp.northeastern.edu/ns/textbase/manuscript" type="intertextual_echo" source="bibliography.xml#De_Staël_Germany" cert="low" xml:id="f40i016">That light of the soul—that spark
          <lb/>of glory which will continue to burn on
          <choice><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><abbr>thro’</abbr><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><expan read="through" type="choice" subtype="del-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><seg read=" " type="choice" subtype="del-content add-element" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/></choice> eternity
            <lb/>I mean a stronger portion of feeling—perception—exist<seg read=" " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><lb break="no"/>ence than belongs to the dull & weake. It is heroism
            <lb/>in the Soldier—self renunciation in the Statsman—self de<seg read=" " type="shy-part" subtype="add-element mod-content" resp="fulltextBot-2.11"/><lb break="no"/>votion in the Martyr—adoration & fruition of existence
            <lb/>in the Recluse. Oh it is the appetite of hunger in
            <lb/>the soul for knowledge virtue & immotality. That it does
          <lb/>not find fuel enough in this clayey world to feed it</itg>
gestures.plaintext: That light of the soul—that spark of glory which will continue to burn on thro’ eternity I mean a stronger portion of feeling—perception—existence than belongs to the dull & weake. It is heroism in the Soldier—self renunciation in the Statsman—self devotion in the Martyr—adoration & fruition of existence in the Recluse. Oh it is the appetite of hunger in the soul for knowledge virtue & immotality. That it does not find fuel enough in this clayey world to feed it
